quiz.title: Pre-calculus: Unit 11 Quiz 2
quiz.subtitle: 11.2: Ambiguous Case (SSA)
quiz.subject: Mathematics
quiz.topic: Determining the number of solutions in SSA

questions.question: In an SSA scenario with acute angle A, if the opposite side $a$ is less than the height $h$, how many triangles can be formed?
questions.explanation: If $a < h$, the side is too short to reach the opposite side of the triangle, so no triangle is possible.

questions.question: Given side $a = 10$, side $b = 15$, and $A = 30^{\circ}$, calculate the height $h$.
Using the values from the previous question ($a=10, b=15, A=30^{\circ}$), how many triangles exist?
questions.explanation: Since $h (7.5) < a (10) < b (15)$, the side $a$ can swing to two different points on the base, creating two distinct triangles.

questions.question: If you find that angle $B_{1} = 40^{\circ}$ in a two-triangle SSA case, what is the value of the second potential angle $B_{2}$?
questions.explanation: The second angle in the ambiguous case is the supplement of the first ($180^{\circ} - 40^{\circ} = 140^{\circ}$).

questions.question: If angle A is obtuse ($A > 90^{\circ}$) and side $a \le b$, how many triangles can be formed?
questions.explanation: If the given angle is obtuse, the opposite side $a$ must be the longest side. If $a \le b$, the triangle cannot close.

questions.question: True or False: The SSA case can result in a single right triangle if $a = b \sin A$.
questions.explanation: When the opposite side equals the height, it is exactly the distance required to form a $90^{\circ}$ angle with the base.

questions.question: In the case where $a > b$, regardless of whether angle A is acute or obtuse, how many triangles exist?
questions.explanation: If the side opposite the given angle is longer than the adjacent side, only one triangle can be formed.

questions.question: Why does the calculator only give one angle when you use $\arcsin$ to find B?
options: The range of arcsin is restricted to [-90°, 90°].
The calculator assumes the triangle is right-angled.
It's a programming error in most calculators.
questions.explanation: Inverse functions only return one value. You must use your knowledge of the unit circle to find the supplementary obtuse angle.

questions.question: Solve for the first angle $B$ if $a = 6, b = 10,$ and $A = 20^{\circ}$. (Round to nearest degree)
In the previous question ($B_{1} \approx 35^{\circ}$), does a second triangle exist?
options: No, because 145 + 20 is too close to 180.
No, because the height is greater than 6.
questions.explanation: A second triangle exists if the given angle A plus the supplement $B_{2}$ is still less than $180^{\circ}$.

scoreMessages.90: Perfect! You navigated the ambiguity with ease.
scoreMessages.70: Good job. SSA is the hardest part of triangle solving!
scoreMessages.50: Remember to compare the opposite side ($a$) to the height ($b \sin A$).
scoreMessages.0: Review the height comparison rules for SSA triangles.
